wiki_catalogs.name: System Overview
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on the Regulens system overview. Explain its purpose as an AI-powered regulatory compliance platform for financial institutions, emphasizing the agent-oriented architecture and event-driven design. Document the high-level components including agents, decision engine, regulatory monitor, and frontend interface. Illustrate the system context with a diagram showing interactions between frontend, backend services, database, and external systems. Describe the core workflows: regulatory change detection, policy generation, risk assessment, and human-AI collaboration. Include both conceptual overviews for beginners and technical details for experienced developers. Provide practical examples of system usage by different user roles (compliance officer, risk manager, administrator). Document the build and execution flow from main.cpp through service initialization. Address common deployment scenarios and performance characteristics.

wiki_catalogs.name: Agent Types
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the Agent Types feature. Thoroughly explain the implementation, responsibilities, and domain-specific logic of each specialized agent: Audit Intelligence Agent for compliance auditing, Regulatory Assessor Agent for regulatory impact evaluation, and Transaction Guardian Agent for real-time transaction monitoring. Document their individual decision-making processes, integration with the Decision Engine and LLM Interface, and interaction with external systems. Include configuration parameters, initialization patterns, and lifecycle hooks. Provide concrete usage examples from the codebase showing how each agent processes input context and generates decisions. Explain relationships with the Agentic Orchestrator and how agent-specific knowledge is updated through feedback loops. Address common issues such as handling conflicting regulatory interpretations or high-risk transaction patterns, and provide troubleshooting guidance.

wiki_catalogs.name: MCDA Algorithms
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the MCDA Algorithms component. Thoroughly explain the implementation of TOPSIS, AHP, PROMETHEE, and ELECTRE algorithms within the Regulens platform. Document the mathematical foundations, normalization methods (minmax, z-score, vector), and weighting strategies for each algorithm. Include concrete examples from the codebase showing how decision matrices are constructed and evaluated. Explain the configuration options for algorithm parameters and performance tuning. Address integration with the frontend's MCDAAdvanced interface for sensitivity analysis and scenario modeling. Provide guidance on selecting appropriate algorithms based on use case requirements, including trade-offs between computational complexity and decision accuracy. Document error handling for inconsistent matrices and timeout scenarios during complex calculations.

wiki_catalogs.name: Change Detection
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the Change Detection subsystem. Thoroughly explain the multi-layered detection algorithms including hash-based, structural, and semantic change detection methods. Document the implementation of Myers diff algorithm for line-level comparison and advanced diff chunk analysis for significance scoring. Include concrete examples from the codebase showing how content normalization, keyword extraction, and term frequency analysis contribute to semantic change detection. Explain the confidence scoring system that combines multiple detection methods and the significance threshold configuration. Address common issues such as false positives in regulatory document updates and strategies for tuning detection sensitivity. Provide performance optimization tips for handling large regulatory documents and memory management considerations for baseline storage.

wiki_catalogs.name: Rule Definition
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the Rule Definition sub-component of the Rule Engine. Thoroughly explain the structure and syntax of rule definitions including rule types (validation, scoring, pattern, ML), condition logic, and action specifications. Document the rule schema with field definitions such as rule_id, rule_type, priority, conditions, and actions. Include concrete examples from the codebase showing fraud detection rules and policy enforcement rules. Explain how rules are stored in PostgreSQL and cached in memory. Describe the validation process for new rules and the role of the LLMInterface in natural language rule conversion. Address common issues like rule conflicts and performance impacts of complex conditions. Provide guidance on best practices for writing efficient, maintainable rules.

wiki_catalogs.name: Semantic Search
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the semantic search sub-feature. Thoroughly explain the implementation of vector-based similarity search using cosine similarity with pgvector, including the embedding generation process using semantic hashing when LLM integration is unavailable. Document the query execution flow from request validation through vector similarity calculation to result formatting. Explain the use of PostgreSQL's vector extension for efficient similarity searches and the SQL query construction with dynamic filtering by domain, knowledge type, and tags. Include concrete examples from the codebase showing how query embeddings are generated and compared against stored vectors. Address configuration options for similarity thresholds, result limits, and age-based filtering. Explain relationships with the VectorKnowledgeBase and frontend components. Provide guidance on optimizing search performance and handling edge cases like empty queries or connection failures.

wiki_catalogs.name: API Clients
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the API Clients sub-component of LLM Integration. Thoroughly explain the implementation details of both OpenAIClient and AnthropicClient classes, including their initialization, configuration, and HTTP communication patterns. Document the core methods for chat completion, streaming responses, and specialized analysis tasks. Include concrete examples from the codebase showing how each client handles API requests, error handling, rate limiting, and usage tracking. Explain the differences in their system prompt strategies and response parsing mechanisms. Address common issues such as authentication failures, rate limiting, and response validation. Make content accessible to beginners while providing sufficient technical depth for experienced developers regarding connection management and performance optimization.

wiki_catalogs.name: Scenario Management
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the Scenario Management sub-feature of the Simulation System. Thoroughly explain how simulation scenarios are defined, configured, and stored within the system. Document the domain model for scenarios including parameters such as regulatory change variables, time horizons, and business impact factors. Describe the API interface for creating and retrieving scenarios via simulator_api_handlers.cpp. Include concrete examples from the codebase showing how ScenarioCreation.tsx in the frontend interacts with the backend to persist scenario configurations. Explain integration points with the Configuration Management system for versioning and reuse of scenario templates. Address common issues such as parameter validation failures and concurrency during scenario editing. Provide guidance on best practices for structuring complex scenarios involving multiple agents and decision pathways.

wiki_catalogs.name: Course Management
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the Course Management sub-feature. Thoroughly explain the implementation details of creating, updating, and managing training courses within the Regulens platform. Document the course creation workflow, including form validation, module management, and prerequisite configuration. Explain the domain model for courses, modules, and prerequisites, including field definitions and relationships. Include concrete examples from the actual codebase, such as the CourseCreation component and training API handlers. Address common issues like prerequisite validation and module sequencing, and provide solutions. Make content accessible to beginners while providing sufficient technical depth for experienced developers. Document configuration options for course types, difficulty levels, and completion criteria.

wiki_catalogs.name: REST API Reference
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive REST API documentation for all Regulens endpoints. Document each endpoint with HTTP method, URL pattern, request/query/path parameters, request body schema (if applicable), and response format (success and error). Include authentication requirements using JWT tokens as defined in auth_api_handlers.cpp. Cover all major modules: agent management (agents/ endpoints), decision engine (decision_api_handlers), regulatory monitor (regulatory_monitor/rest_api_server), rule engine (advanced_rule_engine_api_handlers), knowledge base (knowledge_api_handlers), and LLM integration (llm_api_handlers). For each endpoint, provide example requests and responses, error codes (4xx, 5xx), and descriptions of business logic. Use OpenAPI 3.0 specification format and reference openapi_generator.cpp for schema generation logic. Include rate limiting policies, input validation rules from error_handling_config.json, and CORS configuration details.

wiki_catalogs.name: Metrics Collection
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the Metrics Collection subsystem. Thoroughly explain the implementation of the MetricsCollector class and its integration with the Prometheus client. Document the custom metrics exposed by core components such as agents, decision engine, rule engine, and LLM interface. Include concrete examples from the codebase showing how metrics are registered, updated, and exposed via HTTP endpoints. Explain the data types used (counters, gauges, histograms) and their appropriate use cases. Address performance considerations for high-frequency metric collection and thread-safe access patterns. Provide guidance on adding new metrics, including naming conventions and label strategies. Include configuration options for metric collection intervals and sampling rates.

wiki_catalogs.name: Authentication
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the Authentication sub-feature. Thoroughly explain the implementation of JWT-based authentication, including login, token refresh, and logout flows. Document the secure password hashing mechanism using SHA-256 with salt, and the token generation process using HMAC-SHA256. Explain the integration between the authentication API handlers and the JWT parser for token validation. Include concrete examples from auth_api_handlers.cpp showing the login_user and refresh_token functions. Detail the request/response schemas for /api/auth/login, /api/auth/refresh, and /api/auth/logout endpoints. Address security considerations such as failed login attempt tracking, account lockout after 5 attempts, and secure token revocation. Explain the relationship between authentication and session management via Redis. Provide configuration options for JWT secret, token expiration (24 hours), and refresh token lifespan (30 days).

wiki_catalogs.name: Kubernetes Deployment
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create architectural documentation for Kubernetes Deployment. Describe the custom operator design pattern implemented in the AgentOrchestratorController and ComplianceAgentController. Document the Custom Resource Definitions (CRDs) for agentorchestrators and complianceagents, including their schema structure and lifecycle management. Explain the reconciliation loop implementation that ensures desired state, including resource creation, updates, and deletion. Illustrate how the operator monitors agent health, performs auto-scaling based on Prometheus metrics, and handles configuration updates. Detail the integration between the C++ operator framework and Kubernetes API server for managing deployments, services, and configmaps. Include production-grade considerations such as error handling, logging, and metrics collection for operator reliability.

wiki_catalogs.name: Dynamic Configuration
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create architectural documentation for Dynamic Configuration. Describe the high-level design of the runtime configuration system that allows modifications without service restarts. Document the configuration lifecycle including loading, validation, persistence, and change notification mechanisms. Explain the multi-level scope system (GLOBAL, USER, ORGANIZATION, ENVIRONMENT, MODULE) and how configuration values are resolved across scopes. Detail the database-backed storage in the system_configuration table and the in-memory cache with thread-safe access. Illustrate the workflow for making runtime changes through the API and how listeners are notified of configuration updates. Address security considerations for sensitive configuration values and the audit trail maintained in the configuration_history table. Include system context diagrams showing interactions between the DynamicConfigManager, PostgreSQL database, and application components that consume configuration values.

wiki_catalogs.name: Pipeline Architecture
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the Pipeline Architecture sub-component. Thoroughly explain the implementation of the StandardIngestionPipeline class, including its modular stages (validation, transformation, enrichment, quality checking, deduplication, and compliance). Document the interface methods such as process_batch, validate_batch, and transform_data, and their integration with the overall framework. Include concrete examples from the codebase showing how data flows through each pipeline stage. Explain configuration options via PipelineConfig, stage enablement/disablement, and performance optimizations like caching and batch processing. Address error handling strategies for failed transformations and validation errors, including retry mechanisms and error batch creation. Illustrate relationships with the DataIngestionFramework and source components, and provide guidance on extending the pipeline with custom stages.

wiki_catalogs.name: OpenAI Client
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the OpenAI Client implementation. Thoroughly explain the class structure, initialization process, and dependency injection of ConfigurationManager, StructuredLogger, and ErrorHandler. Document the core functionality including chat completion, streaming responses, and specialized analysis methods like compliance reasoning and structured data extraction. Include concrete examples from the codebase showing how the client handles HTTP requests via HttpClient, manages rate limiting through request timestamp tracking, and implements circuit breaker patterns for resilience. Explain the system prompt generation strategy for different analysis types and the response parsing mechanism for OpenAI's API format. Address common issues such as authentication failures, rate limiting, and response validation. Detail the usage tracking and cost estimation features, including token counting and cost calculation based on model usage. Provide guidance on configuration options like model selection, temperature, and timeout settings, and explain how these affect API behavior and performance.

wiki_catalogs.name: Authentication API
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive REST API documentation for Regulens authentication endpoints. Document the login endpoint (POST /api/auth/login) that generates JWT tokens, logout endpoint (POST /api/auth/logout) for token revocation, me endpoint (GET /api/auth/me) for retrieving current user information, and refresh endpoint (POST /api/auth/refresh) for token renewal. Include detailed request/response schemas, authentication flow diagrams, and JWT token structure. Document error cases like invalid credentials (401), token expiration (401), and rate limiting (429). Provide curl examples for each endpoint and explain the token refresh mechanism. Reference auth_api_handlers.cpp for implementation details of authentication logic and token handling.

wiki_catalogs.name: Getting Started
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on getting started with Regulens. Provide step-by-step installation instructions for both development and production environments using Docker and native builds. Include prerequisites (C++ toolchain, Node.js, PostgreSQL, Redis). Document the setup process with code examples for environment variables, database initialization (schema.sql), and configuration files. Walk through running the system using start.sh and docker-compose.yml. Provide basic usage examples for accessing the frontend, authenticating, and viewing initial system status. Include troubleshooting guidance for common setup issues (port conflicts, dependency installation, database connectivity). Address platform-specific considerations for macOS, Linux, and Windows (WSL). Document verification steps to confirm successful installation with curl commands and UI navigation.

wiki_catalogs.name: Communication Protocol
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for the Communication Protocol section focused on inter-agent messaging and coordination. Explain the implementation details of the Inter-Agent Communicator for message queuing, delivery, and conversation management using PostgreSQL as the message broker. Document message types, priority levels, expiration policies, and acknowledgment mechanisms. Describe the Communication Mediator's role in conflict detection, resolution strategies (majority vote, expert arbitration), and conversation orchestration. Include practical examples from the codebase demonstrating message sending, broadcasting, and conversation initiation. Illustrate integration with the Consensus Engine and Message Translator components. Address reliability concerns such as message retry logic, failed message handling, and delivery status tracking. Provide performance considerations for high-volume message throughput and recommendations for tuning batch sizes and retry delays.

wiki_catalogs.name: Decision Process
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the Decision Process component. Thoroughly explain the end-to-end decision workflow from context ingestion through result generation and storage. Document the DecisionContext model, risk assessment pipelines for transaction, regulatory, and audit decisions, and the decision validation process. Include concrete examples from the codebase showing how DecisionResult objects are constructed with confidence scores and reasoning trails. Explain the integration between the DecisionEngine and MCDAAdvanced components for algorithmic evaluation. Address the decision storage mechanism using PostgreSQL and retrieval patterns for historical analysis. Document performance tracking metrics and accuracy calculation methods. Provide guidance on troubleshooting common issues such as decision timeouts, data validation failures, and inconsistent risk assessments.

wiki_catalogs.name: Source Integration
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the Source Integration subsystem. Document the initialization, connectivity testing, and state persistence mechanisms including database-backed state storage for production reliability. Detail the check_interval configuration and failure handling with exponential backoff through consecutive_failures tracking. Include examples from the codebase showing how different source types implement the check_for_changes() virtual method. Explain the should_check() utility method that determines polling frequency based on configuration and last check time. Address integration challenges with various regulatory body APIs and strategies for handling rate limiting, authentication, and schema changes in external sources.

wiki_catalogs.name: Execution Model
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the Execution Model sub-component of the Rule Engine. Explain the synchronous and asynchronous execution modes, including batch processing workflows and parallel execution limits. Document the execution pipeline from context ingestion to result aggregation, covering the evaluate_transaction and execute_rule methods. Illustrate with examples how transaction data flows through fraud detection rules and policy checks. Describe the integration with the FraudScanWorker for background job processing and real-time transaction monitoring. Address performance considerations such as execution timeouts, caching strategies, and database interaction patterns. Include error handling for rule execution failures and mechanisms for execution tracing. Provide optimization tips for high-volume transaction environments.

wiki_catalogs.name: Vector Storage
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the vector storage sub-feature. wiki_catalogs.name: Prompt Engineering

Include concrete examples from the codebase showing how prompts are constructed for regulatory text analysis, policy generation, and ethical decision-making. Explain the domain-specific prompt templates and their contextual parameters. Address common issues such as prompt injection, response quality degradation, and token limit management. Provide guidance on customizing prompts for specific regulatory domains and optimizing them for better LLM performance.

wiki_catalogs.name: Impact Analysis
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the Impact Analysis sub-feature of the Simulation System. Document how the simulation engine integrates with the Decision Engine (mcda_advanced.cpp) and Rule Engine (advanced_rule_engine.cpp) to project outcomes under different policy interpretations. wiki_catalogs.name: Progress Tracking
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the Progress Tracking sub-feature. Thoroughly explain the implementation details of tracking user progress through training courses. wiki_catalogs.name: WebSocket API Reference
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed WebSocket API documentation for real-time communication in Regulens. Document connection establishment, message framing, event types (e.g., agent_status_update, decision_made, regulatory_change_detected), and disconnection handling. Explain how the websocket_server.hpp integrates with the event_bus to stream agent activities, decision updates, and system alerts. wiki_catalogs.name: Alerting System
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the Alerting System. Document the integration between Prometheus Alertmanager and the internal notification service. Include examples of critical alerts such as agent failure, decision latency spikes, and regulatory data ingestion failures. Explain the alert evaluation engine's role in processing and deduplicating alerts. Provide configuration details for alert routing, escalation policies, and notification channels (email, UI). Address common issues like alert fatigue and false positives, with solutions implemented in the codebase. Include best practices for defining effective alerting rules based on service level objectives.

wiki_catalogs.name: Authorization
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the Authorization sub-feature. Explain the role-based access control (RBAC) system implemented through JWT claims and database-stored permissions. Document how user roles and permissions are extracted from the user_authentication table during login and included in the JWT payload. Describe the get_current_user function that validates JWT tokens and returns user profile with roles and permissions. Explain how the system enforces authorization at the API level by validating JWT tokens and checking required permissions. Include examples from the codebase showing how roles are parsed from JSON arrays in the database and attached to the response. Detail the integration between authentication and authorization flows, showing how the JWTParser validates tokens and extracts user_id, roles, and other claims. Address configuration options for role definitions and permission assignments. Explain how the system handles privilege escalation attempts and unauthorized access through the security monitoring system.

wiki_catalogs.name: Containerization Strategy

Address production considerations such as restart policies, resource isolation, and container security.

wiki_catalogs.name: API Versioning
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive API documentation for API Versioning. Document the three supported version negotiation methods: URL path (/api/v1/resource), Accept header (application/vnd.regulens.v1+json), and query parameter (?v=1). Explain the version lifecycle management with CURRENT, SUPPORTED, DEPRECATED, and SUNSET statuses. Detail the compatibility matrix that defines relationships between versions and the automatic deprecation warnings included in response headers (X-API-Deprecation-Warning). Describe the migration guide system that helps clients transition between versions and the breaking changes tracking mechanism. Document the version-specific endpoint routing and how the system gracefully handles requests to unsupported versions by falling back to the default version. Include examples of version negotiation in different scenarios and best practices for API consumers. Address monitoring capabilities that track version usage statistics and help identify clients using deprecated versions.

wiki_catalogs.name: API Versioning Strategy
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create detailed documentation for the API versioning system in Regulens. Explain the semantic versioning scheme used (major.minor.patch) and how version negotiation works via URL path (/api/v1/, /api/v2/) and Accept-Version header. Document the version router's behavior in routing requests to appropriate handlers based on version constraints. Describe the migration strategy for deprecated endpoints including deprecation timelines, backward compatibility guarantees, and client notification mechanisms. Include configuration options from api_versioning_config.json and migration rules defined in api_migration_strategy.json. Provide examples of version-specific response changes and breaking changes handling. Explain how API consumers should handle version upgrades and test against multiple versions using the versioning service.

wiki_catalogs.name: Visualization Dashboards
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the Visualization Dashboards. Document each Grafana dashboard's purpose, key visualizations, and business value. Explain the 'Compliance Operations' dashboard showing regulatory change processing and policy generation metrics. Detail the 'LLM Performance' dashboard tracking token usage, response latency, and error rates. Describe the 'System Overview' dashboard with infrastructure health metrics. Include guidance on interpreting dashboard panels, identifying trends, and diagnosing issues. Explain how dashboard configurations are managed via ConfigMaps in Kubernetes. Provide instructions for customizing dashboards, creating new panels, and sharing views. Address data refresh rates, time range selections, and dashboard templating features.

wiki_catalogs.name: Security Monitoring
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the Security Monitoring sub-feature. Thoroughly explain the SecurityMonitor class implementation, including threat detection capabilities for SQL injection, XSS, brute force attacks, data exfiltration, and anomalous behavior. Document the SecurityEvent and SecurityAlertRule data structures, including severity levels (LOW to CRITICAL) and event types like FAILED_LOGIN, UNAUTHORIZED_ACCESS, and PRIVILEGE_ESCALATION. Explain the real-time monitoring workflow from event logging to alert triggering and notification. Include examples from security_monitor.hpp showing the detect_sql_injection, detect_brute_force, and check_and_trigger_alerts methods. Detail the integration with authentication to detect failed login attempts and account lockouts. Explain how session management integrates with security monitoring to detect concurrent session violations. Describe the alerting system with multiple notification channels (email, SMS, Slack) and the process for marking false positives. Address configuration options for alert thresholds, time windows, and retention policies.

wiki_catalogs.name: Environment Management
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create architectural documentation for Environment Management. Describe the configuration management system that supports multiple environments (development, staging, production) through environment variables and configuration files. Document the hierarchical configuration loading mechanism from default values to environment-specific overrides. Explain the dynamic configuration capabilities that allow runtime updates without service restarts. Detail the integration between the deployment infrastructure and application configuration, including how Kubernetes secrets and configmaps are consumed by services. Illustrate the environment validation process that ensures required variables are present before startup. Address the differences between docker-compose-based development environments and Kubernetes-based production environments, including service discovery and inter-service communication patterns.

wiki_catalogs.name: Environment Management
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for Environment Management. Thoroughly explain the environment-specific configuration system that supports different settings for PRODUCTION, STAGING, and DEVELOPMENT environments. Document how environment variables are used as the primary configuration source, with strict validation to prevent insecure defaults (e.g., no localhost database hosts in production). Explain the environment detection mechanism and how configuration values are tailored based on the current environment. Detail the validation rules that ensure environment-specific security requirements are met, such as mandatory SSL connections and encryption keys. Describe the configuration loading process that prioritizes environment variables over defaults and the safeguards that prevent accidental configuration leaks between environments. Include practical examples of environment-specific settings for database connections, LLM providers, and security policies. Address deployment considerations for managing environment variables in containerized environments and best practices for environment promotion from development to production.

wiki_catalogs.name: Storage Adaptation
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the Storage Adaptation sub-component. Thoroughly explain the PostgreSQLStorageAdapter implementation as the primary storage backend. Document the StorageAdapter interface methods: store_batch, retrieve_records, and update_record_quality. Include concrete examples from the codebase showing batch storage operations, upsert strategies, and query execution. Explain advanced features like automatic table creation from schema, index management (single-column, composite, GIN, GiST), partitioning strategies (time-based, range, hash), and transaction handling. Detail configuration options via StorageTableConfig and performance optimizations such as prepared statements and batch size tuning. Describe integration with the DataIngestionFramework for data persistence and retrieval. Address common issues like constraint violations, deadlocks, and performance bottlenecks, with solutions including retry mechanisms, connection pooling, and query analysis. Provide guidance on extending the system with additional storage adapters.

wiki_catalogs.name: Client Comparison and Selection
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content comparing the OpenAI and Anthropic clients to guide developers on appropriate selection. Explain the architectural similarities in initialization, error handling, and rate limiting mechanisms between both clients. Contrast their differences in API design (chat completion vs message creation), system prompt strategies (compliance-focused vs constitutional AI), and specialized analysis capabilities (structured data extraction vs ethical reasoning). Document performance characteristics including request latency, token processing speed, and cost efficiency based on real-world usage patterns. Provide decision criteria for selecting between clients based on use cases such as regulatory compliance analysis, ethical decision making, or general text analysis. Include examples showing equivalent tasks implemented with both clients and discuss trade-offs in implementation complexity. Address integration considerations such as configuration management, monitoring requirements, and fallback strategies when one service is unavailable.

Cover CRUD operations for knowledge entries: list (GET /knowledge/entries), get (GET /knowledge/entries/{id}), create (POST /knowledge/entries), update (PUT /knowledge/entries/{id}), and delete (DELETE /knowledge/entries/{id}). Detail the semantic search endpoint (POST /knowledge/ask) that uses vector embeddings for natural language queries, including request format with query text and context. wiki_catalogs.name: Simulation Execution Engine

wiki_overview.content:
<blog>
# Comprehensive Project Analysis of Regulens

## 1. Project Introduction

### Purpose Statement
Regulens is a sophisticated regulatory compliance and risk assessment platform designed to automate financial regulation monitoring, policy generation, and transaction oversight through intelligent agent systems. The system leverages AI-driven decision engines, LLM integration, and real-time data processing to ensure organizational compliance with evolving regulatory frameworks.

### Core Goals and Objectives
- Implement autonomous agent-based architecture for regulatory intelligence
- Enable real-time detection of regulatory changes and compliance risks
- Facilitate human-AI collaboration in policy decision-making
- Provide simulation capabilities for regulatory impact analysis
- Ensure secure, auditable, and resilient operations in financial compliance contexts

### Target Audience
- Financial institutions requiring automated compliance monitoring
- Regulatory affairs teams managing policy implementation
- Risk management departments conducting impact assessments
- Compliance officers overseeing transaction monitoring
- IT teams deploying regulatory technology solutions

## 2. Technical Architecture

### Component Breakdown
The project follows a multi-tiered architecture combining C++ backend services with a modern TypeScript/React frontend, orchestrated through Kubernetes. The system integrates AI agents, rule engines, LLMs, and monitoring tools into a cohesive compliance platform.

```mermaid
flowchart TD
    A[Client Browser] --> B[Nginx]
    B --> C[Frontend React App]
    C --> D[API Gateway]
    D --> E[Agent System]
    D --> F[Rule Engine]
    D --> G[LLM Integration]
    D --> H[Data Ingestion]
    E --> I[(PostgreSQL)]
    F --> I
    G --> J[Vector Knowledge Base]
    H --> I
    K[Monitoring] --> L[Prometheus]
    K --> M[Grafana]
```

### Design Patterns
- **Agent-Oriented Architecture**: Specialized agents (audit, regulatory, transaction) handle domain-specific compliance tasks
- **Event-Driven Design**: Event bus system enables loose coupling between components
- **Microservices via Monorepo**: Independent services organized within a single repository with shared libraries
- **CQRS Pattern**: Separate read and write operations for decision and regulatory data
- **Plugin Architecture**: Tool integration system allows extensible functionality

### System Relationships
The architecture demonstrates clear separation of concerns with well-defined boundaries between frontend, backend services, data storage, and infrastructure layers. Shared components in the `/shared` directory promote code reuse while maintaining modularity.

```mermaid
graph LR
    Frontend[Frontend UI] --> Backend[Backend Services]
    Backend --> Agents[Agent System]
    Backend --> Shared[Shared Libraries]
    Agents --> Rules[Advanced Rule Engine]
    Agents --> LLM[LLM Interface]
    Shared --> Database[(PostgreSQL)]
    Shared --> Cache[(Redis)]
    Shared --> Monitoring[Prometheus/Grafana]
    Infrastructure[Kubernetes Operators] --> Agents
    Infrastructure --> Monitoring
```

### Data Flow
```mermaid
flowchart LR
    A[Regulatory Sources] --> B[Data Ingestion]
    B --> C[PostgreSQL Storage]
    C --> D[Regulatory Monitor]
    D --> E[Change Detection]
    E --> F[Agent System]
    F --> G[Decision Engine]
    G --> H[LLM Processing]
    H --> I[Policy Generation]
    I --> J[Frontend UI]
    J --> K[Human Review]
    K --> F
    F --> L[Audit Trail]
    L --> C
```

## 3. Key Implementation

### Main Entry Points
- **Backend**: `main.cpp`, `api_server.cpp`, `server_with_auth.cpp`
- **Frontend**: `frontend/src/main.tsx`, `frontend/src/App.tsx`
- **Build System**: Root `CMakeLists.txt`, `docker-compose.yml`

### Core Modules
- **Agent System**: `/agents` directory with specialized agents
- **Agentic Brain**: `/shared/agentic_brain` containing orchestrator and decision engine
- **Rule Engine**: `/shared/rules` and `/shared/advanced_rule_engine`
- **LLM Integration**: `/shared/llm` with OpenAI and Anthropic clients
- **Data Ingestion**: `/shared/data_ingestion` framework

### Configuration Approach
The system uses a comprehensive configuration management system with environment validation, dynamic configuration, and API versioning capabilities.

- **Configuration Management**: `/shared/config/configuration_manager.*`
- **API Configuration**: `/shared/api_config/` with routing and versioning
- **Environment Configuration**: `/data/postgres/*.conf` for database settings
- **Kubernetes Configuration**: `/infrastructure/k8s/` with CRDs and operators

### External Dependencies
- **Frontend**: React, TypeScript, Vite, Tailwind CSS (package.json)
- **Backend**: C++ with custom framework, PostgreSQL client
- **Infrastructure**: Kubernetes, Prometheus, Grafana, Redis
- **AI/ML**: OpenAI, Anthropic APIs via LLM clients

### Integration Points
- **Database**: PostgreSQL integration via `/shared/database/`
- **Authentication**: JWT-based auth in `/shared/auth/`
- **Monitoring**: Prometheus metrics in `/shared/metrics/`
- **Caching**: Redis client in `/shared/cache/`
- **WebSockets**: Real-time communication in `/shared/websocket/`

```mermaid
graph TD
    A[External Regulatory Sources] --> B[Web Scraping/Databases]
    B --> C[Data Ingestion Pipeline]
    C --> D[PostgreSQL]
    D --> E[Regulatory Monitor]
    E --> F[Agent System]
    F --> G[LLM APIs]
    G --> H[Policy Generation]
    H --> I[Frontend]
    I --> J[Human-in-the-loop]
    J --> F
    K[Monitoring Tools] --> L[Prometheus]
    L --> M[Grafana Dashboards]
```

## 4. Key Features

### Functionality Overview
Regulens provides a comprehensive suite of regulatory technology features including automated compliance monitoring, AI-assisted policy generation, risk assessment, and collaborative decision-making.

### Implementation Highlights
- **Agent Collaboration**: `/shared/collaboration/agent_streaming.*` enables real-time agent communication
- **Decision Engine**: `/shared/decisions/mcda_advanced.*` implements multi-criteria decision analysis
- **Regulatory Chatbot**: `/shared/chatbot/regulatory_chatbot_service.*` provides natural language interaction
- **Simulation Engine**: `/shared/simulator/regulatory_simulator.*` allows impact analysis
- **Pattern Recognition**: `/shared/pattern_recognition.*` identifies compliance trends

### Feature Architecture

```mermaid
stateDiagram-v2
    [*] --> Idle
    Idle --> RegulatoryChangeDetected: Change Detected
    RegulatoryChangeDetected --> Analysis: Process Change
    Analysis --> DecisionRequired: Need Human Input
    Analysis --> AutomatedDecision: Clear Policy
    AutomatedDecision --> PolicyUpdate: Apply Changes
    DecisionRequired --> Collaboration: Agent Discussion
    Collaboration --> HumanReview: Present Options
    HumanReview --> PolicyUpdate: Approved
    HumanReview --> Reevaluation: Request Changes
    PolicyUpdate --> Monitoring: Active
    Monitoring --> Idle: Continuous Monitoring
```

### Component Relationships

```mermaid
graph LR
    UI[Frontend UI] --> API[Backend API]
    API --> Auth[Authentication]
    API --> Agents[Agent System]
    API --> Rules[Rule Engine]
    API --> LLM[LLM Interface]
    Agents --> Knowledge[Knowledge Base]
    Agents --> Events[Event System]
    Rules --> Decisions[Decision Engine]
    LLM --> Policies[Policy Generation]
    Events --> Audit[Audit Trail]
    Knowledge --> Search[Semantic Search]
    Monitoring --> Alerts[Alert System]
    Auth --> Sessions[Session Management]
```

Sources:
- [main.cpp](Regulens/main.cpp)
- [api_server.cpp](Regulens/api_server.cpp)
- [server_with_auth.cpp](Regulens/server_with_auth.cpp)
- [frontend/src/main.tsx](Regulens/frontend/src/main.tsx)
- [frontend/src/App.tsx](Regulens/frontend/src/App.tsx)
- [shared/agentic_brain/agentic_orchestrator.cpp](Regulens/shared/agentic_brain/agentic_orchestrator.cpp)
